misconceptions.name: Hard-coding grade instead of reading from user

grade is assigned directly as 85

misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the hard-coded 'int grade = 85;' with input from the user, e.g., prompt with 'Enter grade:' and then use 'int grade = input.nextInt();'.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Using bitwise & instead of logical && in conditions
misconceptions.description: The conditional uses the bitwise AND operator (&) with boolean operands instead of the logical AND operator (&&), indicating confusion between these operators.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that '&' is the correct operator for combining boolean conditions in an if statement.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: In Java, '&&' is the standard logical AND operator for conditions in if/else statements; '&' has bitwise meaning and, when used with booleans, evaluates both sides without short-circuiting.
symptoms: Condition written as 'grade >= 80 & grade < 90' instead of 'grade >= 80 && grade < 90'
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion from other contexts (bitwise operators or languages) or assuming '&' and '&&' are interchangeable.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Change '&' to '&&' in compound boolean expressions used for range checks, e.g., 'if (grade >= 80 && grade < 90)'. Review the difference between bitwise and logical operators.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The pattern 'grade >= 80 & grade < 90' strongly suggests misunderstanding of '&' vs '&&', though in this specific case it does not change the outcome.

evidence.note: The if condition uses '&' instead of '&&' between two boolean subexpressions.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Bitwise AND confusion with Logical AND
misconceptions.description: Student uses the bitwise AND operator (&) instead of the logical AND operator (&&) in a conditional statement. The bitwise operator performs bit-level operations and will produce unexpected boolean results.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that & performs logical AND in Java conditionals, or may have confused bitwise and logical operators.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: In Java, && is the logical AND operator used for boolean conditions. & is the bitwise AND operator used for bit-level operations. Use && in if statements to evaluate multiple boolean conditions.
symptoms: Condition may not evaluate as intended
Grade checking logic fails because bitwise result is misinterpreted as boolean
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion between logical operators (&&, ||) and bitwise operators (&, |) in Java.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the single & with && in the condition: change `grade >= 80 & grade < 90` to `grade >= 80 && grade < 90`.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High confidence because the bitwise & operator is explicitly visible in the code at line 16, and using it in a conditional context is a clear error pattern.

evidence.note: Single & (bitwise AND) used instead of && (logical AND) in the conditional expression.
